text: there is a feeling here at the 2011
detroit auto show that the worst is over
that the hometown automakers are out of
survival mode and they're headed towards
a delicious new prospect of possibly
being able to once again make money the
lights are on again the music is
deafening and the smoke machines are
once again trying to pump up the
mystique after two dark dark gears in
the auto industry the strongest of the
US industry automakers is Ford and
they're coming off one of their best
years ever that has been an exciting
year profitably growing around the world
and doing that in a way with global
products and where we can be proud of
the value that we offer this technology
the design the quality it brings you
know fireworks at Ford's press
conference but plenty of butterflies as
they strive to take the industry lead in
electric vehicles and sustainable
mobility going forward they feel this is
the best way to grow the brand and
keeping the black
General Motors coming back from
bankruptcy is also big into economy cars
these days it seems with the new Buick
Verano and chevrolet sonic but economy
cars are a tough sell they have thin
margins compared to the big trucks like
this GMC sierra HD concept which the
company also showed here over at
chrysler is out with the old and in with
the new and I mean everything they threw
away their entire model lineup their
logo and they're bringing out all new
cars and their push to get back to
making money we've got a lot of work to
do and the risk is in not doing such a
thing I mean coming out with 16 products
in one fell swoop is unprecedented and
we've never worked harder I don't think
I've slept in two years I hope the word
of mouth is really the ultimate payback
of us where people start talking about
American cars and the Chrysler brands
vehicles as as being truly truly
relevant
but at Audi the good times never stopped
rolling they invested rather than
retreated during the recession they
tried to spend their way out of it and
is paid off big time for them they are
now an industry cash cow with an all-new
model lineup and they are fetching
prices that are the envy of everyone in
the industry well we wanted to utilize
our strong cash position and strong
profitability position to be bold up
more momentum you know when others are
backing off that's when you really need
to get going we've built 47 new dealer
development projects in the middle of
2009 so the dealer confidence is also
there and we actually upped a marketing
investment to kind of expand brand
awareness and so all these things are
paying off and that makes us very
optimistic about the future from a
revitalized detroit auto show this is
jerry garrett for the new york times
